pull_request.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

update.description:
This pull request is being redirected towards pull request #73 which is a simplified version of this PR.

In this PR, we introduce template specializations which eliminate the overhead of the generic `Plugin` class, and we also introduce the `PluginPtr` class which is (unfortunately) needed in order to support the template specializations.

Hopefully this PR might be less tedious for reviewers after they have looked over pull request #73. The features introduced specifically in this PR are

1. The `Plugin` object can be specialized at compile time to give direct access to any interfaces that can be anticipated ahead of time.

2.  You can cast between different `Plugin` specializations at a one-time map construction cost.
update.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
there's only a few places left in [PluginLoader](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/PluginPtrSemantics/src/PluginLoader.cc) that don't have test coverage. In 3362306 (branch `PluginPtrSemantics_instantiate_unloaded_plugin`), I improve the PluginLoader test coverage by trying to Instantiate a plugin that hasn't yet been loaded and verify that the returned pointer is null. There wasn't a console error message about this, so I added one in 00de9d66e0b3.

Please consider merging with this branch.
content.html:
there's only a few places left in PluginLoader that don't have test coverage. In 3362306 (branch PluginPtrSemantics_instantiate_unloaded_plugin), I improve the PluginLoader test coverage by trying to Instantiate a plugin that hasn't yet been loaded and verify that the returned pointer is null. There wasn't a console error message about this, so I added one in 00de9d66e0b3.

Please consider merging with this branch.

pull_request.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
Template magic.

But more seriously, it's a placeholder template class which allows us to define overloaded versions of the functions `PrivateXXXSpecInterface(~)` where `XXX` is `Get` or `Has`. One overload (the non-templated one) will be called when `XXX<Interface>()` is called and `Interface` matches `SpecInterface`, and that will be the high-performance version of the function. The other overload is called when `Interface` does not match `SpecInterface`, and that will redirect to the normal performance version of the function.

This allows users to call `Get<T>()` or `Has<T>()`, and they'll opaquely get high performance when available and normal performance otherwise, automatically.
content.html:
Template magic.

But more seriously, it's a placeholder template class which allows us to define overloaded versions of the functions PrivateXXXSpecInterface(~) where XXX is Get or Has. One overload (the non-templated one) will be called when XXX<Interface>() is called and Interface matches SpecInterface, and that will be the high-performance version of the function. The other overload is called when Interface does not match SpecInterface, and that will redirect to the normal performance version of the function.

This allows users to call Get<T>() or Has<T>(), and they'll opaquely get high performance when available and normal performance otherwise, automatically.

content.raw:
still fails to compile with clang on macOS

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/100/console

~~~
In file included from src/Plugin.cc:19:
include/ignition/common/Plugin.hh:120:7: error: too few template parameters in template redeclaration
      template <class...> friend class detail::ComposePlugin;
      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
include/ignition/common/Plugin.hh:35:24: note: previous template declaration is here
    namespace detail { template <class, class> class ComposePlugin; }
                       ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
~~~

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/100/console

      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

content.raw: We need to suppress it, because (IIRC) removing the white spaces results in errors complaining about how those operators need to have spaces around them. When I looked into this last time, I failed to find the correct way to suppress the error, but I can take another stab at it (unless someone else is already knowledgeable on the matter).
content.html: We need to suppress it, because (IIRC) removing the white spaces results in errors complaining about how those operators need to have spaces around them. When I looked into this last time, I failed to find the correct way to suppress the error, but I can take another stab at it (unless someone else is already knowledgeable on the matter).

content.raw:
[cpplint doesn't like having spaces around these operators](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/291):

~~~
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:130:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:131:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:132:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:133:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:134:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:135:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
Total errors found: 6
~~~

I personally think it's easier to read with the spaces, but we need to either fix the error or suppress it
content.html:
cpplint doesn't like having spaces around these operators:

./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:130:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:131:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:132:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:133:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:134:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
./include/ignition/common/detail/PluginPtr.hh:135:  Extra space after ( in function call  [whitespace/parens] [4]
Total errors found: 6

I personally think it's easier to read with the spaces, but we need to either fix the error or suppress it

pull_request.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

update.description:
This pull request is being redirected towards pull request #73 which is a simplified version of this PR.

In this PR, we introduce template specializations which eliminate the overhead of the generic `Plugin` class, and we also introduce the `PluginPtr` class which is (unfortunately) needed in order to support the template specializations.

Hopefully this PR might be less tedious for reviewers after they have looked over pull request #73. The features introduced specifically in this PR are

1. The `Plugin` object can be specialized at compile time to give direct access to any interfaces that can be anticipated ahead of time.

2.  You can cast between different `Plugin` specializations at a one-time map construction cost.

pull_request.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

update.description:
I promise this is the last version of this PR that I'm going to open. This plugin framework implementation is finally something that I'm satisfied with. It's a huge PR (and I am really truly sorry for that, but the breadth of the implementation details would make it even worse to break into parts IMO), so I'll try to summarize the key features concisely:

1. The plugin framework can now support arbitrarily many plugins per library, and arbitrarily many interfaces per plugin

2. The `PluginLoader` now returns a generic `PluginPtr` object which contains a generic `Plugin` object that provides access to the interfaces provided by the plugin that was loaded.

3. The `Plugin` object can be specialized at compile time to give direct access to any interfaces that can be anticipated ahead of time.

4. You can cast between different `Plugin` specializations at a one-time map construction cost.

5. The `PluginPtr` class behaves like a `std::shared_ptr` where the plugin instance is shared between them.

6. Interfaces can be retrieved as `std::shared_ptr<T>` objects where `T` is whatever the interface class is. This allows a user to simply query the `Plugin` for the specific interfaces that they want, and then discard the `PluginPtr` that was originally returned by the `PluginLoader`.

One thing that may be controversial in this PR:

* The function that returns interfaces as `std::shared_ptr` objects is called `Plugin::as_shared_ptr`, which violates our style convention. This was an intentional design choice to use the STL style so that it's explicit to the user that the function is converting from an `ignition` data structure to a `std` data structure. If anyone objects to this design choice, we can certainly rename the function to `Plugin::AsSharedPtr`. However, this intentional change in code style is a common pattern that I've seen in other libraries when converting from a custom object type to an STL (or other library) object type.

One problem that this PR does not solve:

* ~~There is potential for abuse in the plugin framework if the user decides to cycle between loading from many different shared libraries. Currently, we have no way of closing shared libraries after the user has loaded them. Whether the library actually gets used after being loaded, or whether anything from the library is still in use, the shared library will remain loaded and active in memory. I have some solid ideas for fixing this, but it can wait for a later PR.~~  This is now addressed in pull request #61

Please don't hesitate to ask me questions about the implementation details in this PR. The use of  templates is likely to be very confusing, even for people who are familiar with templates.
update.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations
